Gather all your vintage loved games, those ones that you can remember as part of who you are, a game that shaped you some how. Now gather all the good things you find in games these days and put them together.... Even better, imagine something more awesome than all that together... This is The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt for me. And I advise you, as an old timer in this game world, don't take my word for it, check out for yourself.

This game excels in lots of ways I can't even point them all out. The story is exciting and very well written, you create empathy for the characters as the story progresses, and I must say, it's better than most movies this days, by the end I've dropped a tear or two in some parts of this awesome story. There's 36 different endings as I know (I can be mistaken) and lots and lots of side quests... You can loose 500 hours on this game easily. It's a very intensive and story driven game, luckily there's subtitles and even translations in every language you can imagine. For the translations you'll have to search online for a guide though, because as I've noticed the game doesn't install all of them at the beginning. It's just a matter of extracting some files to the game folder and you're done.

The RPG element, skills, progression and lore are here to stay, very well balanced between builds and different play styles to choose from... The combat system is good enough to get you hooked although this could be the only point of this game that I think it's good but not AWESOME. I strongly recommend the use of a usb controller tough. (Search for X360ce if you have a plain USB controller like me)

The soundtrack and sound effects of this game gives you such a strong immersive feeling that you will sing these ballads forever and it craves you to play again and again... The other day I've heard a song from the game on tv and I shed a tear.

Ooohhhh the Gwent game.... Sometimes I turn this game on just to play a match... It's so strong that the developer did a different game just for that, although I prefer the feeling I get from this board game than the standalone out there.

The game is a bit chauvinist or sexist if you prefer... Definitely not recommended for children and sensitive ladies out there... But I like to think it's a RPG, so get into your character and go for your closest brothel when you have a change.

The graphics and visual effects are awesome and even if you don't think so the community offers lots of mods to help you in that area. I don't see the need for a graphic mod tough... Just my opinion.

Mods are plenty as the community is big and passionate. I use some, but I don't like to mess to much with this awesome experience as it's lovely already.

I strongly recommend the Game of the Year Edition... It's amazing!

What else?

I think I've covered everything you need to know to buy and start playing this game. Believe me it's a mistake if you don't.

Oh, before this game I considered Skyrim one of the best RPGs, after this I've changed my mind. Not saying that this game is better then Skyrim, (everyone will have his/her own opinion on this matter) BUT, it made me rethink my ranks... If you love/loved Skyrim, check this out!

The story is fantastic and the storytelling is extremely engaging. The characters are all brilliantly written and well developed. The superb voice acting makes them really engaging and easy to connect with. The phenomenal soundtracks make the atmosphere of the game so much more engaging.

While this game had amazing RPG elements, it also lacked some good ones. Barely any consequences for a lot of my actions. I shouldn't be able to steal stuff in other people's houses right in front of their eyes, nor should I be able to bump into everyone while riding my horse, with zero consequences. This leads to the AI being really bad as well.

The AI is horrible. If I'm running around, the NPCs don't even notice and just bump into me. In fact, I could be standing completely still on my horse, unmoved, and people still randomly bump into me like mindless robots. Like, do they not notice a big dude on a horse in the middle of the street? It actually breaks immersion.

For those who think I'm nit-picking, I'm not, at all. I've played much older games with far superior AI. This is not okay in a modern game.

Overall, this game is still truly incredible.

[b]Even with flaws, this work of art is an easy S+ TIER for me.[/b]

Heard about the series through a friend. I'm a big RPG fan but never had a chance to play the witcher series. Forced myself to play from the orignal game through witcher 2 before starting this one. 

With each game its gotten better and better, and it started pretty damn good. I highly recommend this series to anyone who enjoys RPG's or a darker more haunting game. 

Pro's:
-solid plot so far, really REALLY enjoying side quests. Not sure I've ever enjoyed side quests more or felt more immersed in them than i have with this game.  
-fantastic combat. witcher 1 was rough, the second was fantastic, and the witcher 3 offers the closest to perfection i've found in any game. For a challenge, force yourself to avoid roll-spamming.
-Graphically appealing game. says it all, things look awesome.
-Uhhh... I'm addicted to Gwent. I dunno if i'm the only one, but the side games are pretty great for me!
-I can see replay appeal like crazy (already planning on it). Every decision has an effect that changes the outcome of the story, even all the side quests WHICH I CAN'T STRESS ENOUGH, are more awesome than the main plots in some other games. 

cons:
-I do wish there were more happy moments. Its a darker themed game and supposed to paint a more realistic 'human' story, complete with flaws and lose-lose scenarious (for this kind of world, can't have it any other way). While it does have some bright moments, the dark heavily outnumber them. I enjoy a dark themed game, but as a warning to others that may not be built for it, this game is unforgiving at times. I haven't played this in nearly 7 years. And sadly I remember liking it a lot more back then. It's not bad, but it's a very short game, even if you take your time you can easily beat it in only 5 hours. None of the puzzles are particularly hard either, but at least they're somewhat satisfying to solve.

The presentation is excellent though. The old abandoned Aperture Labs are a sight to behold, with ruins so gigantic it's almost awe inspiring. Not that you'll get to explore any of it very much though, the game keeps you on a pretty rigid route. You don't even get to solve any of the puzzles out of order.

The story and characters were great, GLaDOS is one of my favorite villains in all of gaming, and Wheatley and Cave Johnson are hilarious.

Overall it's a good game, but considering how short and easy it is I don't think I can recommend it at full price. But I'll still give it a positive review, because it's definitely worth playing if you can pick it up on sale.
